text: Can the historic data API error messages be improved? A lot of the time when someone comes here with a problem it's hard to tell if they're doing something wrong - like passing in invalid arguments - or if the API is just being its usual flakey self

elements.text: Can the historic data API error messages be improved? A lot of the time when someone comes here with a problem it's hard to tell if they're doing something wrong - like passing in invalid arguments - or if the API is just being its usual flakey self

text:
Have you ever considered more sophisticated security settings? For example:

• Only allowing API access from specific IP addresses
• Generating access keys with specific permissions. e.g. generate a key that only allows read access to the account statement endpoint. This key can then be used by a reconciliation application without it being an attack vector for placing bets
The use of certificates seems an oddity compared to other APIs both financial (e.g. Binance, IG Index) and not (e.g. AWS). They seem to be a bit of a pain point with new users, especially those on Windows

elements.text: Have you ever considered more sophisticated security settings? For example:
Only allowing API access from specific IP addresses

Generating access keys with specific permissions. e.g. generate a key that only allows read access to the account statement endpoint. This key can then be used by a reconciliation application without it being an attack vector for placing bets

The use of certificates seems an oddity compared to other APIs both financial (e.g. Binance, IG Index) and not (e.g. AWS). They seem to be a bit of a pain point with new users, especially those on Windows

text: Hi <@UBS7QANF3>,  yes, we can get something added to the historical data dev backlog for this.

text: Is there any roadmap to increase liquidity in the spanish exchange? In poker, regulations allow international liquidity. Wondering if that is being considered for the exchange as well?

text: Hi Mo, We have started looking at allowing API access from specific IP addresses. Initially, this is likely to be something that we provide on a request basis, but without specific API/front end functionality

elements.text: Hi Mo, We have started looking at allowing API access from specific IP addresses. Initially, this is likely to be something that we provide on a request basis, but without specific API/front end functionality

text: Similarly, we do have the ability to manually create App Keys with specific permission (no betting etc) but there's no planned front end functionality with regards to this

elements.text: Similarly, we do have the ability to manually create App Keys with specific permission (no betting etc) but there's no planned front end functionality with regards to this

text: We made some changes to the non-interactive login documentation towards the end of 2021 to help improve the onboarding experience

text: Hi <@U02MHP63N4R> - no plans to do this at the moment, although it would be a nice to have.  This would have been a Stream service had the Stream API architecture been available when this was first introduced.

elements.text: Hi
- no plans to do this at the moment, although it would be a nice to have.  This would have been a Stream service had the Stream API architecture been available when this was first introduced.

text: I think you need to add a line in the XCA documentation to make sure the signature algorithm is SHA 512 - see this thread for background: <https://betcode-org.slack.com/archives/C4H05ML2E/p1647009507466239>

elements.text:
Hi all, I'm hoping for some help from experts. I've been trying to get to grips with the API using Python so that I don't have to outsource it but I'm running in to the following error:

raise APIError(None, exception=e)
betfairlightweight.exceptions.APIError: None
Params: None
Exception: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='
identitysso-cert.betfair.com

', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /api/certlogin (Caused by SSLError(SSLError(9, '[SSL] PEM lib (_ssl.c:3932)')))

I'm pretty green so my apologies if this is something obvious - I saw this was asked on the Betfair Developer Forum and the OP was directed here as Liam said it had been answered - it was over a year ago though so I can't find the thread.....

text: Hi <@U011VL3CA2Y> - Regulation in Spain only allow ring-fenced, that is national, liquidity for betting exchanges. Unlike poker where there is an agreement in place with Portugal, France and Italy that allows the sharing of liquidity

elements.text: Hi

- Regulation in Spain only allow ring-fenced, that is national, liquidity for betting exchanges. Unlike poker where there is an agreement in place with Portugal, France and Italy that allows the sharing of liquidity

text: Hi <@U01C12ZEADQ> – unfortunately, there are no plans to provide this data at the moment.

elements.text: Hi
– unfortunately, there are no plans to provide this data at the moment.

text: When we initially launched the service back in 2017 data for all Exchanges (.com, .it and .es) was recorded and packaged as part of each monthly file on <https://historicdata.betfair.com/>. However, due to time constraints, a dedicated historical data site for Spain and Italy was out of scope. The .es and .it data was subsequently purged from the existing published files to reduce complexity and the overall size of the stored files.

elements.text: When we initially launched the service back in 2017 data for all Exchanges (.com, .it and .es) was recorded and packaged as part of each monthly file on

. However, due to time constraints, a dedicated historical data site for Spain and Italy was out of scope. The .es and .it data was subsequently purged from the existing published files to reduce complexity and the overall size of the stored files.

text: Thanks <@UNW8Q88EL>. That's unfortunate indeed. Is there anything that could help Betfair be interested into restoring recording? Say, a 10-20 people set willing to buy? I believe from a UI/localization point of view a dedicated site is probably not necessary.. if you are interested into these piece of data, your english is usually reasonable :wink:

elements.text: Thanks

text: Hi <@U01C12ZEADQ> - i have asked the dev team to check if the past data (recorded May 2015 to ~ Dec 2017) is still held in raw storage.  I believe this may have been purged post processing, so there's a small chance that the raw data may still exist.

elements.text: Hi

- i have asked the dev team to check if the past data (recorded May 2015 to ~ Dec 2017) is still held in raw storage.  I believe this may have been purged post processing, so there's a small chance that the raw data may still exist.

text: We can request that the data recording is kicked off again, but will still want/need to separate this from the current offering for the reasons described previously.  An easier path (removing additional front & back end dev, international legal & compliance requirements etc.) would be record and provide the data to interested customers via a separate distribution channel i.e. e-mail file share

elements.text: We can request that the data recording is kicked off again, but will still want/need to separate this from the current offering for the reasons described previously.  An easier path (removing additional front & back end dev, international legal & compliance requirements etc.) would be record and provide the data to interested customers via a separate distribution channel i.e. e-mail file share

text: I think the latter sounds like a more enticing proposal, and I believe email file share would be absolutely acceptable.

elements.text: I think the latter sounds like a more enticing proposal, and I believe email file share would be absolutely acceptable.

text: From my point of view, and I believe i'm not the only one, I think the most useful historical data stretches up to 2-3 years in the past., not more

elements.text: From my point of view, and I believe i'm not the only one, I think the most useful historical data stretches up to 2-3 years in the past., not more

text: Apologies if I've missed a communication, but I seem to recall last time this channel was open you hinted at potentially removing the in-play bet delay for passive (i.e. 'maker' rather than 'taker') orders. Is that something you are still exploring?

elements.text: Apologies if I've missed a communication, but I seem to recall last time this channel was open you hinted at potentially removing the in-play bet delay for passive (i.e. 'maker' rather than 'taker') orders. Is that something you are still exploring?
